title: How to prove that a certain sound is more rich than others by their physical properties - Quora

response.answer_text: Richness is like beauty: ity is a perceived (subjective) aspect of a sound, an esthetical judgement by individuals - and that is something that is hard to “prove” (the eye of the beholder and all that). But, there is also the fact that between simple and complex timbres there is a difference in the number and spread of over- and undertones, and the rule of thumb is that “richer” sounds tend to have more of those. So pictures (or better: movies) of a frequency analyzer can be used to “prove” this. Test oscillator (very boring “poor” sine wave, no under- or overtones, at all, the sound of “beeeeeep”):  Lush synth sound from a Korg synthesizer:  About the same pitch, but many more visible (and audible) consonant overtones. Still pretty regular though, an even richer sound will have more dissonant under- and overtones:  This is not “proof” though, this is, at best, evidence. If someone claims that the second sound is more “rich” to their ears than the third, you cannot “disprove” that. Perception cannot be “proven” in any way. Making the overtones in the high frequency area (above 3 kHz) more pronounced adds to the feel of richness:
You cannot. Rich or more rich or less rich is not a quantifiable attribute. It is a subjective attribute and will vary with each listener.
